exception.name: ErrorInvalidTime
exception.description: This exception is thrown if the SE API function updateTime fails because the supplied time parameters are not valid or fall outside the acceptable range. The function attempts to update the Secure Element's current time, but the provided time parameters contain invalid values (out-of-range year, month, day, hour, minute, second), causing the time validation to fail.

javadoc.summary: This class defines the exception ErrorInvalidTime that is thrown if the supplied time parameters are not valid or are outside valid ranges.
javadoc.description: This exception is thrown when the updateTime function receives time parameters that fail validation checks. Time parameters include year, month, day, hour, minute, and second values that must fall within valid ranges for a valid date and time. ErrorInvalidTime indicates that one or more time parameters are outside the acceptable range or represent an invalid date/time combination. When this exception occurs, the time is not updated and the Secure Element's current time remains unchanged. Recovery requires supplying valid time parameters that represent a legitimate date and time within the acceptable range.

specification.requirement: The function updateTime SHALL validate all supplied time parameters before updating the Secure Element's current time. Time parameters (year, month, day, hour, minute, second) must fall within valid ranges: year within supported range, month 1-12, day 1-31 (depending on month), hour 0-23, minute 0-59, second 0-59. If any time parameter is outside the valid range or represents an invalid date combination, the function SHALL raise the exception ErrorInvalidTime and reject the time update without modifying the Secure Element's time.
specification.applicability: Time management operations - updateTime function only

condition.scenario: Year parameter is outside valid range
condition.description: The supplied year value is outside the valid year range supported by the Secure Element
condition.trigger: The user supplies a year that is before the minimum supported year or after the maximum supported year for the device (e.g., year 1970 when minimum is 2000, or year 2099 when maximum is 2050). When setCurrentSeTime validates the year parameter, it is found to be outside the acceptable range and ErrorInvalidTime is raised.

condition.scenario: Month parameter is out of range
condition.description: The supplied month value is not between 1 and 12
condition.trigger: The user supplies a month value outside 1-12 range (e.g., month 0, month 13, or month -1). When the month validation occurs, the out-of-range value is detected and ErrorInvalidTime is raised.

condition.scenario: Day parameter is invalid for the specified month and year
condition.description: The supplied day value is invalid for the month and year combination (e.g., February 30, April 31)
condition.trigger: The user supplies a day value that is not valid for the specified month/year (beyond the valid day range for that month, considering leap years). When date validation checks the day against the month and year, the invalid combination is detected and ErrorInvalidTime is raised.

condition.scenario: Hour, minute, or second parameters are out of range
condition.description: The supplied time-of-day parameters are outside valid ranges (hour 0-23, minute 0-59, second 0-59)
condition.trigger: The user supplies time values outside valid ranges (e.g., hour 25, minute 60, second -1). When the time-of-day validation occurs, these out-of-range values are detected and ErrorInvalidTime is raised.

condition.scenario: Time parameter combination represents an impossible date/time
condition.description: The combination of time parameters represents an impossible or logically invalid date/time
condition.trigger: The user supplies time parameters that, while individually might be in range, form an impossible combination (e.g., February 29 in a non-leap year, or invalid timestamp format). When comprehensive date/time validation occurs, the logical impossibility is detected and ErrorInvalidTime is raised.

executionSequence.step: User/application calls updateTime function with time parameters (year, month, day, hour, minute, second)
Function receives the time parameters from the caller
Function performs preliminary input validation on all time parameters (type checks, null checks)
Function validates individual time parameter ranges (year range, month 1-12, day 1-31, hour 0-23, minute 0-59, second 0-59)
If any parameter is outside its valid range → ErrorInvalidTime raised, function exits
If parameter format is invalid or inconsistent → ErrorInvalidTime raised, function exits
Function validates date validity (e.g., February 29 only in leap years, day validity for the specific month)
If the date combination is invalid → ErrorInvalidTime raised, function exits
If all validation passes, function checks authorization and device state
Function initiates communication with Secure Element and prepares time update command
Function transmits validated time parameters to Secure Element
Function processes the Secure Element response confirming time update
Function returns to caller with updated time

recovery.step: Verify time parameter ranges - review the TR-03151-1 specification for valid ranges for each time parameter (year, month, day, hour, minute, second)
Check year parameter - verify the year is within the supported range for the device (consult device specifications for minimum and maximum year)
Validate month parameter - ensure month is between 1 and 12 (inclusive)
Validate day parameter - ensure day is valid for the specified month and year (e.g., no February 30, no April 31)
Check for leap year - verify that February 29 is only used in leap years (divisible by 4, except century years unless divisible by 400)
Validate time-of-day parameters - ensure hour is 0-23, minute is 0-59, second is 0-59
Correct invalid parameters - modify time parameters to represent a valid date and time
Retry updateTime with corrected parameters - re-attempt the time update with valid time values
Implement input validation in application - add client-side validation to check time parameter ranges before calling updateTime
Use system time functions - consider using operating system or standard library time functions that validate and normalize time automatically

postconditionality.state: The Secure Element's current time remains completely unchanged. The rejected time update does not modify the device's clock or time configuration. The device continues to maintain its previous time value.
The time update operation is not performed and has no effect on the Secure Element's time. No clock adjustment occurs. The time is rejected at validation.
No device state is modified. Configuration, stored data, and operational parameters remain unchanged. The rejection occurs at input validation before Secure Element communication.
The operation does not reach the Secure Element communication stage. The error is detected and raised before device-to-Secure Element interaction occurs.
The time update operation fails cleanly without any partial effects or side effects. No state corruption or incomplete operations result from the invalid time parameters.
The application can immediately retry the operation with corrected time parameters. No recovery procedures or device intervention is required - the error is input data error.

notes.note: ErrorInvalidTime is thrown ONLY when time parameter validation detects out-of-range or invalid values - it is the most specific exception for time value validation failures
This exception indicates input data error (invalid time parameters) rather than a system or device error
Critical distinction from ErrorSetCurrentSeTimeFailed: ErrorInvalidTime indicates parameter validation failure, while ErrorSetCurrentSeTimeFailed indicates system-level time update failure
Exception is raised during the parameter validation phase (steps 4-5), before any Secure Element communication or time modification
After this exception, the device time remains completely unchanged and the application can immediately retry with corrected input
This exception has High severity because it represents either a coding error in the application or potential security issues with invalid timestamps
Time parameter validation is a mandatory input validation requirement - strict range checking prevents invalid time values from being set
The valid year range depends on device specifications - consult device documentation for minimum and maximum supported years
Leap year calculations must follow standard rules: divisible by 4 except for century years, which must be divisible by 400
If this exception occurs frequently, it suggests the application may not be properly validating time parameters - application-side validation should be added
Time parameter validation occurs consistently regardless of current device state, authorization, or other factors
Applications should implement client-side time validation to detect format errors early and provide better user experience
ErrorInvalidTime is an expected, normal exception in workflows where external or user-supplied time values might be processed
The error message should ideally indicate which specific time parameter is invalid to facilitate debugging and correction
Standard library time functions should be used when possible to avoid manual time validation errors

scenario.name: Scenario 1: Time Synchronization with User Input
scenario.description: An application synchronizes the Secure Element's time with an external source. The application receives time parameters and calls updateTime to update the device time. If the supplied time parameters are invalid, ErrorInvalidTime is raised. The application must validate the time before transmission and handle validation errors.
scenario.errorContext: Invalid time parameters prevent time synchronization

scenario.name: Scenario 2: Automated Time Synchronization with NTP Integration
scenario.description: An automated system synchronizes device time using NTP (Network Time Protocol). The system receives NTP timestamp and converts it to individual time parameters (year, month, day, hour, minute, second). When calling updateTime, if the converted parameters are invalid, ErrorInvalidTime is raised. The system must validate the conversion and handle conversion errors.
scenario.errorContext: Invalid time from NTP conversion prevents automatic time synchronization

scenario.name: Scenario 3: Time Input Processing and Validation Pipeline
scenario.description: An application processes time values from various sources (configuration, user input, external APIs). The application validates each time value before using it in updateTime. When invalid time parameters are encountered, ErrorInvalidTime is raised, and the application logs the error and uses fallback time.
scenario.errorContext: Validation of externally-supplied time parameters for validity

scenario.name: Scenario 4: Time Synchronization with Format Conversion
scenario.description: An application converts time from various formats (ISO 8601, Unix timestamp, custom format) to SE API time parameter format. The application calls updateTime with the converted parameters. If the conversion results in invalid parameters, ErrorInvalidTime is raised, indicating conversion error.
scenario.errorContext: Time format conversion error detected via invalid parameter validation

implementationContext.note: Time parameter validation is a fundamental input validation requirement for time update operations
Time parameter ranges are strictly defined to ensure only valid date/time values are accepted
Supported year range depends on device specifications and Secure Element capabilities - typically 1970-2099 or similar
Month must be 1-12, day 1-31 (depending on month), hour 0-23, minute 0-59, second 0-59
Leap year logic must be correctly implemented: year divisible by 4 is leap year, except century years (divisible by 100) unless also divisible by 400
Applications should implement client-side validation to detect format errors early and provide better user experience
ErrorInvalidTime is detected during input validation before Secure Element communication - no device state is affected
Standard library time functions should be preferred for time validation to avoid manual error-prone calculations
